instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3113: What is 820-3113? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD – once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
[COLOR=#6A6E71][FONT="][SIZE=14px]Significant liquid damage with pins 4 & 5, as well as the traces totally dissolved (Red wine, Arg!).

[COLOR=#6A6E71][FONT="][SIZE=14px]Replaced <CHIP>U5410</CHIP>: Pins 4 & 5 completely burnt out.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
I ran a wire from <CHIP>U5410</CHIP> pin 4 to <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> Pin 2 and from <CHIP>U5410</CHIP> Pin 5 to <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> Pin 3 to try and get around the traces being burnt out. (Can someone confirm this is right please?!)
 
Replaced <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> which was dead.


Board now powers up but fan runs high & <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> is reading erratic voltages.

Can someone suggest some measurements I should be taking?


I'm new to the board repair business and know enough to be dangerous. :)
With a little direction though I should find my feet really quickly. All suggestions and input appreciated.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5410</CHIP> is not important right now, the board will work without for now.
Measure both <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> and 3 from F7040 to the actual pin on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> to see if the traces are ok. 
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5818"]
Measure both <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> and 3 from F7040 to the actual pin on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> to see if the traces are ok.
[/quote]

I get continuity from F7040 to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>:Pin3, if I understand your question correctly.

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5818"]
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present?[/QUOTE]

<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>:Pin1 is bouncing between 1.2v & 1.4v.
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>::Pin3 measured at Pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7410</RESISTOR> is giving me 12mV. :/
F7040 is giving me 12.59v on both ends.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: <CHIP>U2650</CHIP>::Pin1 is giving me 3.2v.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Any suggestions on what to check next?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Check resistance between F7040 and pin 1 from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, the value should be about 182K (the value of <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR>), now measure resistance between F7040 and pin 48 from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, the value should be about 150K (the value of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>)....

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
Thanks for the instructions!

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> doesn't have a pin 48, it stops at 40 (or 41 really) right?

threads.message: [SUB]Reading from the wrong board...[/SUB]

threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 5850"]Check resistance between F7040 and pin 1 from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, the value should be about 182K (the value of <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR>), now measure resistance between F7040 and pin 48 from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, the value should be about 150K (the value of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>)....[/QUOTE]


So, now that I have the right board. (sorry about that, I'm working on a bunch of old ones I haven't been able to fix).

I have no continuity between;
F7040 and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>::Pin1
F7040 and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>::Pin8.

Looking at it though, I'm not so sure there would be...

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: F7040 to pin 1 should be 182K and pin 48 should be 150K, check again.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
I cleaned the points and checked again.

I'm getting 30 to 40 Mohms (it's not a stable reading) on both pins.


(Going to start checking every component btween <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>::Pin1 and F7040)

Happened to get another 3115 in today and checked <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> to F7040; Yep, 182 & 150k Ohms exactly. :/
This is good though, I have something to look for now.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Corroded pins 2 on each resistor or completely dead resistor.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
When I measure the resistors (7402 and 7403) I get the correct values.

7402 & 7403 have been removed, traces etc. cleaned up and replaced...

But the resistance between them and F7040 is still in the Mega Ohm ranges. On the working board I have here, it is 0ohms on Pin2 and then the expected 182k & 150k on Pin1, respectively.

Is it a single wire between F7040 & the two resistors?

What could be messing with the resistance?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Can I just run a jumper wire across?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: Not to F7040, but you can take it from <CAPACITOR>C7513</CAPACITOR> if continuity to F7040 is good on that one.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
F7040 to <CAPACITOR>C7513</CAPACITOR>::Pin1 is 0Ohms.
<CAPACITOR>C7513</CAPACITOR>::Pin1 to <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> is 6MOhms.

So I'm guessing if we jumper-wire from <CAPACITOR>C7513</CAPACITOR>::Pin1 to <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> I should have power back there. :)

Yeeew, going to give it a try and report back.


Edit:
Could one of the capacitors on that line be faulty and causing this issue?
Maybe the issue is a component and not the trace.

I'm getting the 12.6v at <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> now, but the behaviour is exactly the same.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message:
Yes.

I am now getting 182kOhms & 149kOhms after running a jumper wire from <CAPACITOR>C7513</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3113</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Liquid damage.
threads.message: You need to figure out why there is not power to those resistors. There may be more stuff that is not getting power cause of that same broken trace.
